I was a very sick baby until given lactose free formula. Lactase supplements and lactose free products are a life saver. Apparently being born with it is rare. Its a genetic thing. It’s normally developed post infancy (people with lactose intolerance). Thankfully my child doesn’t have that issue.

Fact, not fun or disturbing: by adulthood you are almost lactose intolerant, because you don't need momma's milk anymore, you stop making lactase, which is why it becomes harder to digest dairy products.

Other pro-tip I learned in dairy class: whole milk and cream have less lactose than skim milk and low fat milk.  I had already noticed that I could actually drink those without getting sick, (as long as I didn't have too much,) but I didn't understand why.  It's actually pretty simple: basically, if you remove one component - in this case fat - the percentages of every other component goes up, because you can't have a substance that only adds up to 95%.

Valio, a Finnish dairy product manufacturer, uses chromatographic separation in addition to the hydrolysis with lactase enzyme - in industrial scale and at rather competitive price point. The chromatographic separation actually removes half of the lactose which means the end product isn't as sweet and it really tastes exactly the same as normal milk while being completely lactose free. Valio's lactose removal technologies might involve also use of semipermeable membranes - or something like that - which can be used to split the milk into components which can be processed and combined separately to produce any kind of end product imaginable. Google "Valio Eila lactose free technology" for more information. Edit: actually it seems that the membrane separation is the thing nowadays, not the chromatographic separation any more.

For the groups information:
Calcium chloride is sold as a pickling salt to increase the firmness of non-fermented pickles, if you want to use food grade calcium chloride.

As for milk processing, the continuous method is only cheaper if you can sustain a certain flow rate of milk.
The constant flow of milk on an industrial scale actually flushes the excess proteins and lipids out of the column before it becomes an issue. If you can't sustain that flow rate, it's not great, and there's a fair amount of research done in being able to switch a column out of a continuous batch line without interrupting that lines production.
It's not so much a different set of problems as a difference in industrial production vs non-industrial production.

The more concerning bit not covered in all this is potential changes to the pH of the milk and the subsequent changes to the milk proteins that can occur.
People tend to be aware of caseins denaturing, since that can become a smelly brick very quickly, but they're not the only protein in milk.
The most interesting ones, in my opinion, are the beta-lactoferrins, which are ultimately why humans should drink animal sourced milk: They literally boost the innate immune system of the person drinking the milk and increase calcium, magnesium, and iron uptake in our digestive tract.
They have use in biotech too.
They can be used to remove RNA from DNA, and, with some time, separate single stranded DNA from Double Stranded DNA. Which is like the first step to any bio-lab sample prep.

Here in Norway, there aren't many options for lactose-free products, but the biggest dairy company has two kinds of milk: lactose-free, and lactose-reduced. IMO, the sweet-tasting milk is utterly useless, and that method should be saved for specific applications where you'd otherwise add sugar.

I'm lactose intolerant, here in Germany 1L of normal full milk (3.5% fat) costs around 0.5€.
The same amount of the cheap lactose free milk (also 3.5% fat) is around 0.7-0.9€ per liter. This type of milk is produced by one of the first two methods you described and tastes sweeter ( like a tablespoon of sugar into a normal glas of milk). Good for baking or Latte Macchiato but not for drinking in my opinion.
The ultrafiltration method is also available (e.g. from Hansano, Arla or Landliebe) and is sold as "less sweet" for 1.6-1.8€ per liter. Thus the last method is (at least in Germany) the most expensive to buy as a consumer, but the taste is superior, I can not taste a difference to normal milk.
Actually the final addition of lactase has two reason, one to get rid of the residual lactose (<0.03% in comparison to the other methods with <0.1%) and second to add a little sweetness because otherwise the milk would be not sweet enough to taste like normal milk.

I'm a chemistry student and we did a similar project, using different methods to create lactose free milk. The methods we used were different from yours and gave some interesting results. In method one we used the chemical properties of lactose to remove it from the mixture, by simply adding ethanol and letting the lactose crystallize. This gave some problems after with removing the ethanol but all of the lactose was removed. We also used a very small filter (similar to a HPLC filter) to remove the lactose. This also removed the fats and a very small amount of lactose still got through. In the end the project was fun to do because we were allowed to come up with our own solutions and gave some nice results
